name: ficus-carica-magnolia
wildlife-value: Insects, wasps and birds eat the fruit
edibility: This is probably the largest fig available on the market. The asymmetric fruit has a bronze skin and an amber flesh. Ripens from mid-July through August. Pick fruit as early as possible because of the open ostiole or it would split and turn sour easily. Magnolia is best suited for preserving.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: The infructescence is a ripened receptacle (syconium), not an ovary, that forms in late summer or fall on new wood.  The large, asymmetric fruit has a bronze skin and an amber flesh. Ripens from mid-July through August.  Fruits develop without the need for cross pollination.
flower-description: Magnolia Fig has minute, petalless flowers that are in the stem tip on the leaf axils.
leaf-description: The green leaves are large and thick, are 5-10 inches long and 4-7 inches across and deeply, palmately lobed with three to five sinuses lobed. The upper surface is green and rough with hairs and the underside is paler and smooth.
bark-description: Silver gray smooth bark becomes more bumpy with age.
stem-bud-terminal: Only 1 terminal bud, larger than side buds
poison-symptoms: Phytophotodermatitis from the white, milky sap.
